title: What are the implications of speech deprivation on memory and identity according to these experiments?
first_phrase: In the last part of this text, the author discusses the importance of distinguishing between experimental manipulation of speech versus pathological speech disorders in medical practice. The author then recounts their own unpublished work on magnetism and memory, in which they demonstrate that subjects can be made to forget their own name through suggestion. The experiments were circulated among doctors in the 1800s, but the author did not release them commercially. This raises questions about the ethics of withholding scientific information for the sake of perceived incompleteness or lack of recognition.

last_phrase: In conclusion, while there may still be unresolved issues concerning the physiological and psychological aspects of aphasie, the significance and impact of the aphonic experiments are undeniable. By depriving someone of the ability to speak without physical impediment, the experiment allows us to truly understand the intricate connection between our brains and vocal organs, shedding light on the enigmatic mechanisms that govern human communication.
